data.body:
In a file called header.php.

Hovering over the html5 `<header>` tag shows a php `header()` tooltip:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038062/13682336/37890e78-e6f9-11e5-83f6-90fdb2e87a00.png)

It also shows it on the `</header>` tag.

I have php 7 installed on the system.

data.title: Distribute 64bit Windows
data.body:
VS Code 64 bit compile is desperately needed.

When you use the explorer extension "Open with Code" and are looking at files in c:\windows\System32 on a 64 bit OS, the File System Redirector gets in the way and sends you to the SysWOW64 directory, which may not contain your file.  UX is horrible.

For example, right click on C:\Windows\System32\BestPractices\v1.0\Models\Microsoft\Windows\WebServer\WebServer_Model.ps1 and select "Open with Code"

Code starts, but has a blank file in the editor that's dirty and ready for a save.

Since the 64 bit Explorer doesn't populate the SysNative tree there's no way to use the explorer extesion on this and similar files.

data.title: [PHP] Switch case definition inserts intellisense instead of newline
data.body:
OS: Windows 10

Steps:
1. Launch VS Code
2. Open a php file
3. Add this code inside html
    <?php 
switch (condition) {
    case 1
}
?>
4. Add a : after "case 1"
5. Press Enter
6. Intellisense adds $_COOKIE

Expected:
Pressing Enter returns newline after colon

data.title: stopOnEntry
data.body:
Should we support this at some point:

**Stop at Entry**
Setting the stopAtEntry flag will cause the debugger to break immediately on the entry point to the application. This allows you to start stepping through your code without setting breakpoints.

data.title: Add suggested completions for key chords

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
With more complex key chords, it would be incredibly helpful to have "suggested" completions, based on the first element of the chord. For example, consider the following complicated workflow:
1. You type `CMD + K`
2. Visual Studio Code waits for the next key of the chord (but doesn't tell you what valid options could be typed)
3. User forgets or doesn't know the shortcut he wants, so he hits `ESCAPE` 
4. User hits `F1` to search for the desired command and keyboard shortcut
5. User hits `ESCAPE`
6. User executes keyboard shortcut

Instead, what should happen is that VS Code should show the users all of the key chords (or perhaps most commonly used commands _by that specific user_, based on telemetry data), that could possibly be pressed.

This would have the following benefits:
- Significantly improve the user experience
- Ease the learning of new keyboard shortcuts
- Tailor the Visual Studio Code environment to each user (optional)

Cheers,
Trevor Sullivan
Microsoft MVP: PowerShell
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: Missing "focus" command to focus on the project
data.body: There's options for _View: Focus into Side Bar_ and _View: Focus on Working Files_, but there isn't any option for _View: Focus into Open Project_. Please add this. Cheers, Trevor Sullivan Microsoft MVP: PowerShell https://trevorsullivan.net https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: [php] Highlighting / Colorization of Variables in Strings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is broken or just not there, see the examples on the PHP Page.

http://php.net/manual/de/language.types.string.php
http://php.net/manual/de/language.types.string.php#language.types.string.parsing

It would be nice to have this, its really difficult to spot variables in strings without it.

Example (simple case):
echo "This is a {$variable}";
echo "This is a $variable too";

The variable {$variable} and $variable should be highlighted.

Example (a bit more complex from PHP page):
<<<'EOT'
My name is "$name". I am printing some $foo->foo.
Now, I am printing some {$foo->bar[1]}.
This should not print a capital 'A': \x41
EOT;

All this is a string, so no highlighting (Nowdoc), variables are not parsed.
In Heredoc there should be highlighting as variables are parsed. (see linked page above)

data.title: Mac OS X :: 0.10.10 :: Regex find for new line isn't working
data.body: I'm trying to use a regular expression to replace the new line character `\n` with null. The regular expression isn't being matched, however. Am I doing something wrong here, or is it a bug? Cheers, **Trevor Sullivan** Microsoft MVP: PowerShell https://trevorsullivan.net https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: New setting to exclude folders from file watching
data.body:
**Assignees:**
- [x] Windows @alexandrudima 
- [x] OS X @seanmcbreen 
- [x] Linux @weinand 

A new setting `files.watcherExclude` can be used to modify the list of excluded folders from file watching. The format is glob patterns and we always had a hardcoded default that now is the default setting.
- Verify you can change the setting and after a restart you do not get file events for configured patterns (e.g. verify in the explorer)
- OS X only: verify that for a very large folder (e.g. chromium sources, typescript) you see a short CPU spike in the beginning that drops after a while). now add a setting to exclude the large folder and verify the CPU spike no longer occurs.

data.title: Test Tour: Manual Test Script Node (JavaScript)
data.body:
# Copied from VS needs to be adapted to VS Code

Test basic scenarios Use the following Templates:

•Create a new Starter Azure Node.js Express 3 Starter Project (JavaScript) in c:\src using the project template in Node.js -> JavaScript 
•Create a new Starter Azure Node.js Express 3 Starter Project (TypeScript) in c:\src using the project template in Node.js -> TypeScript

If you are testing io.js follow the "Configuring your project to use io.js" steps to configure your project:
• https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejstools/wiki/io.js-and-ES6-support#configuring-your-project-to-use-iojs 

Walk through these steps with both templates
•Wait for  npm install  to finish executing in the background (see details in the Output npm pane)
•Set a breakpoint in app.js at the line (or app.ts):

var app = express()
•Set a breakpoint in routes\index.js (or routes\index.ts) at the line that begins with

res.render('index'
•F5 to start debugging
◦Ensure the browser launches (http://localhost:1337)
◦Ensure both breakpoints are hit
◦Ensure the url loads successfully 

•Walk through the “Profiling” and “Start your profiling session” sections in the Profiling docs, and verify things look as they do in the screenshots ◦ https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejstools/wiki/Profiling#profiling 
◦https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejstools/wiki/Profiling#start-your-profiling-session

•Walk through the “Browsing/Installing new npm packages in the GUI” section ◦ https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejstools/wiki/Npm-Integration#browsinginstalling-new-npm-packages-in-the-gui 
◦Try different VS themes, and make sure things are readable and nothing looks out of place.

•Walk through the Test Explorer documentation: ◦https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejstools/wiki/Test-Explorer#test-explorer

•Browser/Node.js-side editing ◦Create a new directory named “hello”, and right click to add a new javascript item “item1.js” to the directory
◾Verify that the directory display name changes to “hello (node)”
◾Verify that Ctrl + Space in item.js produces a completions list with “process” in it. 
◾Right click the directory, and select “Set as Content (Browser code)”
◾Verify that the directory display name changes to “hello (browser)”
◾Verify that the build action of the item.js file is now set to “Content”
◾Add a new javascript file, “item2.js” to the directory, by right clicking the directory and using “Add New Item”
◾Verify that the directory name is still set to “hello (browser”)
◾Ctrl + space in the “item2.js” file that has opened, and verify that “document” appears in the completions list
◾F2 to change the name of the directory, and verify that the edit label is “hello”
◾Type a new directory name - “goodbye”
◾Verify that the name of the directory is “goodbye (browser)”

•Right click the project, Add new item, select the “Dockerfile” item template, and verify that the file is generated successfully.
•Interactive window ◦Open the Node.js Interactive Window using Ctrl+K, N
◦Run  .npm install azure --save-dev  
◦Verify that the output is readable and doesn’t include any odd characters once the command finishes executing 
◦Verify that a new entry has appeared in the  npm > dev  node in Solution Explorer and there are no errors/warnings

data.title: taskService.run promise should always complete
data.body:
Currently `taskService.run` returns a promise, but this promise does not always complete.
IMHO this promise should always complete with a `TaskSummary` as it would make the `taskService` API nicer and easier to program against.

data.title: TypeScript Intellisense extremely lagged after upgrading to 0.10.10
data.body:
After upgrading to 0.10.10, my Intellisense is now extremely inconsistent and laggy. It happens with most auto-complete attempts, but is most easily reproduced by this [excerpt from another comment I made](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3791#issuecomment-194300157):

> When I hit ctrl+space on "trycatch" to get the snippet intellisense option, it will consistently lag about 10sec. Ctrl+space thereafter will be immediate as long as I don't edit anything. But if I hit spacebar just after trycatch (to move the cursor off of the symbol), then left arrow (to return to the end of "trycatch"), and then ctrl+space, there will be the 10 second lag again.

There are some possibly related issues that might help. At first I thought it was related to [this javascript issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3791), but it appears not to be the case. Since it is only lagged and not completely failed, I don't think it is related to [this Typescript issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3889), but it could be. It also resembles [this other Format Code issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3652), but again in my case it does not completely fail. Perhaps because [my project](https://github.com/ibgib/stackGib) is not as large and theirs is possibly just extremely lagged to the point of crashing. 

@egamma suggests in [this comment](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3791#issuecomment-194774281) that is the files glob that may be the culprit. We're going to look into this further as I was not aware it was considered an Atom-specific practice, but I would think it unlikely to be the problem as it worked previously without problems and that there are multiple other issues regarding Intellisense problems after the upgrade.

Then collapse this block, and you will see that comments still present. But ideally, we need to collapse these comments with codes in this block:
![collapse](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2539541/13671230/59ee17dc-e6d7-11e5-9d95-ef36948fc491.png)

Thanks.

data.title: vscode version 0.10.10 update failed on ubuntu 14.04 x64?
data.body:
dotnet version output

```
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-beta-001675)
Product Information:
 Version:     1.0.0-beta-001675
 Commit Sha:  N/A
Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  14.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 Runtime Id:  ubuntu.14.04-x64
```

I updated vscode to version 0.10.10. Then I installed csharp extension. Then I logged off my computer for half an hour. when I returned I saw an error, 

> csharp is not compatible with 0.10.8, please un-install.

so I checked the version, it was 0.10.8. I restarted the machine and still same error. I'm clueless how this happened. update was successful, otherwise it would not let me install csharp extension.

data.title: [json] Add telemetry event when user edit a json file for Azure RM.
data.body: When we refactored JSON to an extension, we lost the telemetry on how many users edit a JSOMN file for Azure RM. We need to add it back with the support telemetry support that @SofianHn added.

data.title: [php] Provide more specific PHP scopes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
_Requested on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35894983/vscode-theme-color-for-php_

Currently `class`, `function`, `public`, etc. are only scoped with the `keyword` scope. It would be good if more specific scopes for more granular theming was possible, `function` should have the `function` scope as per https://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars for example.

This may be fixed doing away with the current implementation and taking up a community plist for tokenizing instead.
